abstract: Our daily roundup of Web gems includes a brain-controlled computer, the one person that Conan O’Brien follows on Twitter and a new site that broadcasts your purchase history to your followers.
snippet: Our daily roundup of Web gems includes a brain-controlled computer, the one person that Conan O’Brien follows on Twitter and a new site that broadcasts your purchase history to your followers.
lead_paragraph: Monday’s roundup of interesting items from around the Web, selected by the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times:

headline.main: What We’re Reading: Conan’s Twitter Buddy and New York in Pixels

abstract: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac owned more than 131,000 properties between them at the end of 2009, according to annual filings.
snippet: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac owned more than 131,000 properties between them at the end of 2009, according to annual filings.
lead_paragraph: Home ownership in the United States ranks up there with motherhood and apple pie. The government has championed it for decades through tax breaks, mortgage guarantees and, most recently, the herculean task of keeping Americans in their homes after the housing market collapse. But government subsidies of the American Dream also have a darker side: when things head south, taxpayers end up stuck with the costs.

headline.main: The Dark Side of Home Subsidies
headline.print_headline: The Dark Side of Home Subsidies

byline.original: By Agnes T. Crane and Neil Unmack

abstract: Charles Thacker, the lead designer on the Alto, the Xerox PARC prototype of the modern personal computer, won the Turing Award.
snippet: Charles Thacker, the lead designer on the Alto, the Xerox PARC prototype of the modern personal computer, won the Turing Award.
lead_paragraph: This is the big week for awards — in computing as well as movies. The Turing Award, often called the Nobel prize of computer science, was announced on Tuesday and the 2009 winner was Charles P. Thacker.

headline.main: A Talk With Charles Thacker, the Turing Winner

abstract: Two of the world’s computing powerhouses have started a war of words around their forthcoming tablet computers.
snippet: Two of the world’s computing powerhouses have started a war of words around their forthcoming tablet computers.
lead_paragraph: Such is the hype around tablet computers that Hewlett-Packard and Apple have taken to beating each other up over products that no one can even buy yet.

headline.main: H.P. Barks, Then Bites Apple on the iPad
